top_comment.text:
Julius Caesar was to a large degree a Greorge W Bush of his time. He used 
lies and fear to start wars so he could steal riches and make himself 
popular. What's more, he twisted facts (and in turn history) to make it 
seem as if the Celts were vile savages and his war crimes were justified, 
which thanks to archaeology we now know was not the case at all. It's no 
wonder he was an inspiration for Emperor Palpatine. As for Brutus, anyone 
who is for democracy should be sympathetic to the cause of destroying a man 
who would give himself absolute power, because be it politics or 
corporations or the media, hoarding power is never good. I don't see how 
Brutus could be an opportunist knowing that his betrayal would have major 
negative consequences.﻿

comments.text:
+Mark Arandjus You are projecting modern values into a fundamentally 
different culture.

Rome was an inherently militaristic state. It was ingrained into their 
political system, their religion, their gender identities, everything. 

You didn't have to 'justify' war. War was viewed as a good and natural 
thing, an opportunity for men to win honour and to bolster the Roman 
economy. 

Even if Caesar was every bit as bad as you accuse him and George Bush of 
being, the average Roman probably wouldn't mind too much. He vanquished the 
enemy and that is that.
comments.author: Merry Machiavelli

comments.text:

Obviously The Romans had a superiority complex, but they said that the 
Celts had no culture and were filthy illiterates, while as we now know they 
had roads, trade routes, quite accurate calendars, greater equality between 
the sexes that Romans ever did, and lots of gold, which I'm sure caught 
Caesar's attention.

current politicians, but the fact of the matter remains that George Bush 
(and every other president thus far) was democratically elected in and 
democratically elected out. 

The Romans viewed most non-Romans as vile savages, other than defeating 
them in battle, I doubt Caeser really changed anyones opinions on Celts. 
The Romans also didn't have a concept of 'war crimes', totally annihilating 
the enemy in a crushing victory would probably be perceived as a good 
thing. He didn't have to 'justify' anything to anybody.

top_comment.text:
On March 15th, 44 BCE, Roman dictator Julius Caesar was assassinated by a 
group of about 60 of his own senators. Why did these self-titled Liberators 
want him dead? And why did Brutus, whose own life had been saved by Caesar, 
join in the plot? Kathryn Tempest investigates the personal and political 
assassination of Julius Caesar.﻿

comments.text:
Well, for a start we have lots and lots of coins and inscriptions that 
testify to exactly when someone ruled, what their main accomplishments were 
and when their rule was ended and someone else's rule began. We even have 
coins that these conspirators minted during their shortlived coup featuring 
a cap symbolizing liberty and a dagger symbolizing their act of killing the 
tyrant (i.e. Julius Caesar). So when someone lived, ruled, and died is as 
certain as anything can be. On the other hand, exactly *how* they ruled and 
exactly *how* they died is less certain but we have different accounts by 
different authors - some of them of them of course with their own agenda - 
but comparing their accounts and applying some elementary deduction with 
the existing knowledge about Roman society can get you pretty far. Rome was 
a literate society and it had a large literate elite who wrote down 
histories, biographies and other things of note. Much of it is lost, but 
enough has survived from critical periods of Roman history to shed light on 
key events.

The time of Julius Caesar and the fall of the Roman Republic is one of the 
best documented because ancient Romans themselves valued the writings 
concerned with this period as it was already then understood as having been 
a crucial turning point in history. In terms of literature, we have both 
official writings by historians but also many collections of letters by 
prominent members of the Roman elite. Being part of the elite, these 
individuals had both common agendas and conflicting agendas as they vied 
for power and prestige among each other. In Roman literature, you never get 
a uniform version of history - Rome never had a centralized narrative or a 
centralized propaganda machine that could eliminate undercurrents of 
criticism and that's a very good thing for historians trying to tease out 
what true and what's not, what's likely and what's not, etc.
comments.author: neuralvibes

top_comment.text:
I cannot claim to know much about this field of Roman history but I would 
like to share my thoughts. Perhaps a more knowledgeable person can rectify 
any mistakes I make in my presumptions :)

I'm interested more in the legacy left behind by Brutus. His descent from 
an arguable more upright ancestry might have incentivized the Liberators to 
invite him, as a means to justify and legitimize their killing of Caesar. 
After all, his ancestor, Lucius Junius Brutus, had done the noble thing to 
remove a tyrant and return democratic rule to the people. 

Yet in the minds of the Liberators, were they as noble? IMO backstabbing a 
man because of political reasons would have been the least democratic means 
to an end, yet they claim to be bring freedom. Furthermore how sure is it 
that the same democratic return is ensured? Did they fear a dictatorship or 
a limit to their personal political clout? Maybe they had sought to fill in 
that political vacuum themselves, bickering and politicking instead of 
effectively ruling the empire, as the video did mention.

And where does Brutus play in this? The video did make him out to be the 
young man, so perhaps he was naive and succumb to smooth talking? I find it 
hard to believe that a legacy 400+ years ago would have a moral burden on 
him, but I cannot be sure. Ultimately the legacy he himself leaves to us 
cannot be so black & white. Dante was mentioned for writing Brutus into the 
deepest parts of Hell, but was he regarding the act of betrayal as the 
worst sin or Brutus? Perhaps Dante had to choose a famous figure in history 
whose act was condemned enough in his social and cultural context and 
personal judgement. 

I think it really brings into question too the issue of liberty and 
democracy in modern times. If the rulers of an empire or country provide 
stability and well being for the people, is authoritarian rule truly that 
evil? I would even go as far to say that democracy and freedom has been 
idealized and worshipped on such a level that masks the limits they can 
really provide as a social and political institution.

In the end, we cannot categorize Brutus as a hero or villain, before we 
answer the question about the costs of liberty :)﻿
top_comment.author: SoashAng

comments.text:
In Roman times all states were basically on perpetual war with each other 
over resources. Rome got really good at war, in large part because of 
Julius Caesar, and was able to give its subjects the Pax Romana under 
Emperor rule. Although it continued to fight at its borders.

Dictatorship by proven educated leaders worked at the time, because it was 
a harsh world. if a certain civilization wanted to survive, it had to kill. 

But entropy teaches us all systems decay. So tyranny inevitably came and 
the idea of the glory of the Empire faded. 
Just like the glorious idea of our faux democracy in the West 

I just sometimes wonder how great Caesar could have been

In the Nietzsche view Brutus fucked up for humanity. In the democratic or

comments.author: Gabriel Gomez-Centeno

comments.text:
I think the lessons of Rome, ancient Greece and even the 'democratic' 
countries today all tell the same story: belief in democracy is at best a 
fallacy. I would like to point out at this point that in ancient Greece, 
the country was filled with city states and depending on which period of 
time you were referring to, political institutions are very different. For 
example Sparta was an oligarchy during the time of the Socrates and Plato.

On the other hand, Athens was a democracy, but a severely limited one with 
voting power resting in a patriarchal society built upon the backs of 
slaves. What you mentioned does resonate as well and it brings into 
question: is democracy achievable and legitimate without first achieving 
equality between all (wo)men? After all, Athens as the hallmark of Western 
historical democracy was a society that gave political power to the rich 
male citizens, without any consideration of the poor or the slaves or even 
women. 

As mentioned, I am no expert so take my word with much salt :)
comments.author: SoashAng

comments.text:
I would say we cannot judge Rome by modern standards nor what people did 
back then or why. even today people can't agree what democracy means. Rome 
was more democratic than many parts of the world true (except ancient 
Greece-which they ended up conquering), but was very far from being 
anything close to what we would consider free. Simply put, it was an empire 
built on pillage, genocide, slavery and ruled by a small elite of its most 
wealthy citizens. Those wealthy citizens were the only ones concerned with 
sharing power with anyone.  Ironically, the Caesar period was sort of the 
halfway mark for the empire's lifespan (in the west) and the later half was 
marked with near constant civil war. With one dictator after another vying 
for power. The lesson of Rome is not one of democracy, but of power and the 
will to use it sadly.
comments.author: MonkeyspankO

captions.text:
What would you do if you thought 
your country was on the path to tyranny?

If you saw one man gaining too much power,
would you try to stop him?

Even if that man was
one of your closest friends and allies?

These were the questions haunting
Roman Senator Marcus Junius Brutus in 44 BCE,

the year Julius Caesar 
would be assassinated.

Opposing unchecked power 
wasn't just a political matter for Brutus;
it was a personal one.

He claimed descent
from Lucius Junius Brutus,

who had helped overthrow the tyrannical
king known as Tarquin the Proud.
Instead of seizing power himself,

the elder Brutus
led the people in a rousing oath
to never again allow a king to rule.
Rome became a republic

based on the principle that no one man
should hold too much power.

Now, four and a half centuries later,
this principle was threatened.

Julius Ceasar's rise 
to the powerful position of consul
had been dramatic.

Years of military triumphs 
had made him the wealthiest man in Rome.

And after defeating his rival
Pompey the Great in a bitter civil war,
his power was at its peak.

His victories and initiatives, 
such as distributing lands to the poor,
had made him popular with the public,

and many senators vied for his favor 
by showering him with honors.

Statues were built, 
temples were dedicated,

and a whole month was renamed,
still called July today.
More importantly, the title of dictator,

meant to grant
temporary emergency powers in wartime,

had been bestowed upon Caesar 
several times in succession.

And in 44 BCE, 
he was made dictator perpetuo,
dictator for a potentially unlimited term.
All of this was too much for the senators

who feared a return to the monarchy
their ancestors had fought to abolish,

as well as those whose 
own power and ambition
were impeded by Caesar's rule.

A group of conspirators 
calling themselves the liberators

began to secretly discuss
plans for assassination.

Leading them were
the senator Gaius Cassius Longinus
and his friend and brother-in-law, Brutus.

Joining the conspiracy was not 
an easy choice for Brutus.

Even though Brutus had sided with Pompey 
in the ill-fated civil war,

Caesar had personally intervened 
to save his life,

not only pardoning him
but even accepting him as a close advisor
and elevating him to important posts.

Brutus was hesitant to conspire against
the man who had treated him like a son,
but in the end,

Cassius's insistence and Brutus's own fear
of Caesar's ambitions won out.

The moment they had been waiting for
came on March 15.
At a senate meeting

held shortly before Caesar was to depart
on his next military campaign,
as many as 60 conspirators surrounded him,

unsheathing daggers from their togas
and stabbing at him from all sides.
As the story goes,

Caesar struggled fiercely
until he saw Brutus.

Despite the famous line, "Et tu, Brute?" 
written by Shakespeare,
we don't know Caesar's actual dying words.

Some ancient sources claim
he said nothing,

while others record the phrase, 
"And you, child?",

fueling speculation that Brutus may have
actually been Caesar's illegitimate son.

But all agree that when 
Caesar saw Brutus among his attackers,
he covered his face and gave up the fight,

falling to the ground 
after being stabbed 23 times.
Unfortunately for Brutus,

he and the other conspirators 
had underestimated Caesar's popularity
among the Roman public,

many of whom saw 
him as an effective leader,
and the senate as a corrupt aristocracy.

Within moments of Caesar's assassination,
Rome was in a state of panic.
Most of the other senators had fled,

while the assassins barricaded themselves
on the Capitoline Hill.

Mark Antony, 
Caesar's friend and co-consul,
was swift to seize the upper hand,

delivering a passionate speech 
at Caesar's funeral days later

that whipped the crowd into a frenzy 
of grief and anger.

As a result, the liberators 
were forced out of Rome.

The ensuing power vacuum 
led to a series of civil wars,

during which Brutus, 
facing certain defeat, took his own life.
Ironically, the ultimate result

would be the opposite of what
the conspirators had hoped to accomplish:
the end of the Republic

and the concentration of power 
under the office of Emperor.

Opinions over the assassination of Caesar 
were divided from the start
and have remained so.
As for Brutus himself,

few historical figures have inspired 
such a conflicting legacy.

In Dante's "Inferno," he was placed 
in the very center of Hell

and eternally chewed by Satan himself
for his crime of betrayal.
But Swift's "Gulliver's Travels"

described him as one of the most
virtuous and benevolent people to have lived.

The interpretation of Brutus as either
a selfless fighter against dictatorship
or an opportunistic traitor

has shifted with the tides 
of history and politics.
But even today, over 2000 years later,
questions about the price of liberty,

the conflict between 
personal loyalties and universal ideals,

and unintended consequences
remain more relevant than ever.

title: The great conspiracy against Julius Caesar - Kathryn Tempest
